Layouts & Positioning

Intro to Positioning

Sometimes we want more control over the positioning of our elements than the inline-block or float methods will allow. This is where it can be helpful to understand how to use the position property combined with the box offset properties.

The default value of the position property is static, which means that it just exists within the normal flow of the document and won’t accept any box offset properties.

When to use static? This is the default value that 99% of your elements will use, including your gridlex columns.  

 

Relative Positioning

Relative behaves the same as static unless it is paired with box offset properties (top, left, right, bottom).

.relative{
  position: relative;
  top: 10px;
  left: 30px;
}

The offset properties identify where an element will be moved from its original position. Thus, the left property with a value of 30 pixels will actually push the element towards the right, from the left, 30 pixels. The top property with a value of 10 pixels will push an element towards the bottom, from the top, 10 pixels.

When we position the element using the box offset properties, the element overlaps the element below it rather than moving that element down as the margin or padding properties would.

When to use relative? When you want to make slight adjustments to the positioning, without moving other elements or as a parent container for an absolute element. 

Absolute Positioning

The absolute value for the position property is different from the relative value in that an element with a position value of absolute will not appear within the normal flow of a document, and the original space and position of the absolutely positioned element will not be preserved. Absolutely positioned elements will always occupy the exact spot of their parent that you tell them to.



Absolutely positioned elements are positioned in relation to their closest relatively positioned parent element. Should a relatively positioned parent element not exist, the absolutely positioned element will be positioned in relation to the <body> element.

When you use absolute? When you need to place an element in a specific spot on top of another element, that you couldn’t achieve with other values. Typically in layering. 

Fixed Position

A fixed element is positioned relative to the viewport (the user’s visible area of a web page), which means it always stays in the same place even if the page is scrolled.

The box offset properties of top, right, bottom, and left properties are used.

.fixed-container {
  position: fixed;
  top: 0;
  left: 0;
  width: 100%;
}

When to use fixed? For headers, sidebars or elements that stay fixed in a certain position as you scroll.  

 

In Practice 

For example, in this section that holds the banner is position relative, the white diagonal triange and ‘Bali Intensive’ tag are position absolute, and the orange chat box is position fixed.
